articles.headline: Evolution’s Backers in Kansas Start Counterattack
articles.snippet: Moderates hope to gain seats on the State Board of Education and reverse teaching standards.
articles.abstract: Moderates hope to gain seats on the State Board of Education and reverse teaching standards.

articles.headline: Growing Debate as Doctors Train on New Devices
articles.snippet: Doctors must learn to implant increasingly sophisticated devices without compromising patient safety.
articles.abstract: Doctors must learn to implant increasingly sophisticated devices without compromising patient safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, rival cardiologists in Rock Hill, S.C., decided to learn how to perform a lucrative new procedure, implanting a defibrillator, a device that protects against fatal heart rhythms.

articles.headline: Mel Gibson: The Speed of Scandal
articles.snippet: The speed at which the scandal surrounding Mel Gibson unfolded was almost as stunning as Mr. Gibson’s tirade itself.
articles.abstract: The speed at which the scandal surrounding Mel Gibson unfolded was almost as stunning as Mr. Gibson’s tirade itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 31 — Almost as stunning as Mel Gibson’s anti-Jewish tirade when arrested on suspicion of drunk driving in the early hours of last Friday was the speed at which the scandal unfolded, doing serious damage to one of Hollywood’s most valuable careers along the way.

articles.headline: Japan Makes More Cars Elsewhere
articles.snippet: Hitting a milestone, Japanese carmakers produced more vehicles abroad than at home for the first time last fiscal year.
articles.abstract: Hitting a milestone, Japanese carmakers produced more vehicles abroad than at home for the first time last fiscal year.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, July 31 — Hitting a milestone, Japanese carmakers produced more vehicles abroad than at home for the first time last fiscal year, an industry group announced Monday.

articles.headline: Tax Cheats Called Out of Control
articles.snippet: A Senate report estimates that cheating on federal income taxes totals as much as $70 billion a year.
articles.abstract: A Senate report estimates that cheating on federal income taxes totals as much as $70 billion a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: So many superrich Americans evade taxes using offshore accounts that law enforcement cannot control the growing misconduct, according to a Senate report that provides the most detailed look ever at high-level tax schemes.

articles.headline: Israel Pushes On Despite Agreeing to Airstrike Lull
articles.snippet: Israel’s defense minister told  Parliament that the army “will expand and deepen its operations against Hezbollah.”
articles.abstract: Israel’s defense minister told  Parliament that the army “will expand and deepen its operations against Hezbollah.”
articles.lead_paragraph: METULLA, Israel, July 31 — As Israel poured soldiers and artillery shells into southern Lebanon, it vowed Monday to press ahead with its war on Hezbollah and made a number of airstrikes after promising a 48-hour pause in its air campaign.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: An Image Popular in Films Raises Some Eyebrows in Ads
articles.snippet: The caricature of the sassy overweight black woman is troublesome to some marketers and media scholars.
articles.abstract: The caricature of the sassy overweight black woman is troublesome to some marketers and media scholars.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 200 pounds plus — most of that pure attitude — she is hard to miss.

articles.headline: From Lebanese- American Financiers, Differing Views on the Strife
articles.snippet: Lebanese-Americans have considerable influence in international financial circles, especially on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Lebanese-Americans have considerable influence in international financial circles, especially on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ziad K. Abdelnour and George F. Boutros have much in common.

articles.headline: For Lebanese, Calm Moment to Flee Ruins
articles.snippet: Across southern Lebanon on Monday, people took advantage of a lull in the Israeli airstrikes to seek safety farther north.
articles.abstract: Across southern Lebanon on Monday, people took advantage of a lull in the Israeli airstrikes to seek safety farther north.
articles.lead_paragraph: BINT JBAIL, Lebanon, July 31  In a bathroom, a basement, and a storage room full of yarn, people in this embattled southern town waited for the bombs to stop. They ate pieces of bread, and the grain that they had in their cupboards. Days passed. Food ran out. They began to lose track of time.

articles.headline: Mel Gibson: The Speed of Scandal
articles.snippet: Almost as stunning as Mel Gibson's anti-Jewish tirade when arrested on suspicion of drunk driving in the early hours of last Friday was the speed at which the scandal unfolded, doing serious damage to one of Hollywood's most valuable careers along...
articles.abstract: Almost as stunning as Mel Gibson's anti-Jewish tirade when arrested on suspicion of drunk driving in the early hours of last Friday was the speed at which the scandal unfolded, doing serious damage to one of Hollywood's most valuable careers along the way.     In a little over 24 hours, Mr. Gibson's arrest and subsequent behavior in Malibu had already prompted talk of a claimed cover-up, an exposé, worldwide news coverage, an apology and then a full-blown push for alcohol rehabilitation, even as his representatives and executives at the Walt Disney Company rushed to catch up with the event's effect on the filmmaker's movie and television projects with the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 31 - Almost as stunning as Mel Gibson's anti-Jewish tirade when arrested on suspicion of drunk driving in the early hours of last Friday was the speed at which the scandal unfolded, doing serious damage to one of Hollywood's most valuable careers along the way.

articles.headline: Evolution’s Backers in Kansas Start Counterattack
articles.snippet: God and Charles Darwin are not on the primary ballot in Kansas on Tuesday, but once again a contentious schools election has religion and science at odds in a state that has restaged a three-quarter-century battle over the teaching of evolution.  ...
articles.abstract: God and Charles Darwin are not on the primary ballot in Kansas on Tuesday, but once again a contentious schools election has religion and science at odds in a state that has restaged a three-quarter-century battle over the teaching of evolution.     Less than a year after a conservative Republican majority on the State Board of Education adopted rules for teaching science containing one of the broadest challenges in the nation to Darwin's theory of evolution, moderate Republicans and Democrats are mounting a fierce counterattack. They want to retake power and switch the standards back to what they call conventional science.

articles.headline: Israel Pushes On Despite Agreeing to Airstrike Lull
articles.snippet: As Israel poured soldiers and artillery shells into southern Lebanon, it vowed Monday to press ahead with its war on Hezbollah and made a number of airstrikes after promising a 48-hour pause in its air campaign.     ''The fighting continues,'' Pri...
articles.abstract: As Israel poured soldiers and artillery shells into southern Lebanon, it vowed Monday to press ahead with its war on Hezbollah and made a number of airstrikes after promising a 48-hour pause in its air campaign.     ''The fighting continues,'' Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said. ''There is no cease-fire, and there will not be any cease-fire in the coming days.''
articles.lead_paragraph: METULLA, Israel, July 31 - As Israel poured soldiers and artillery shells into southern Lebanon, it vowed Monday to press ahead with its war on Hezbollah and made a number of airstrikes after promising a 48-hour pause in its air campaign.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Japan Makes More Cars Elsewhere
articles.snippet: Hitting a milestone, Japanese carmakers produced more vehicles abroad than at home for the first time last fiscal year, an industry group announced Monday.     The 12 car and truck makers in Japan, which include Toyota, Honda and Nissan, built 10....
articles.abstract: Hitting a milestone, Japanese carmakers produced more vehicles abroad than at home for the first time last fiscal year, an industry group announced Monday.     The 12 car and truck makers in Japan, which include Toyota, Honda and Nissan, built 10.93 million vehicles at their overseas factories in the year ended March 31, according to a report by the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association. That compares with 10.89 million vehicles that they produced in Japan, the group said.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, July 31 - Hitting a milestone, Japanese carmakers produced more vehicles abroad than at home for the first time last fiscal year, an industry group announced Monday.

articles.headline: From Lebanese- American Financiers, Differing Views on the Strife
articles.snippet: Ziad K. Abdelnour and George F. Boutros have much in common.      Born on the same day in Beirut to prominent Christian political families, each left Lebanon to work in the United States in the 1980's and made a fortune on Wall Street: Mr. Ab-deln...
articles.abstract: Ziad K. Abdelnour and George F. Boutros have much in common.      Born on the same day in Beirut to prominent Christian political families, each left Lebanon to work in the United States in the 1980's and made a fortune on Wall Street: Mr. Ab-delnour, as a junk-bond salesman during Michael R. Milken's glory days at Drexel Burnham Lambert and Mr. Boutros as a top deal maker for Credit Suisse First Boston.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ziad K. Abdelnour and George F. Boutros have much in common.

articles.headline: An Image Popular in Films Raises Some Eyebrows in Ads
articles.snippet: At 200 pounds plus -- most of that pure attitude -- she is hard to miss.      Her onscreen presence takes on many variations, but she is easily recognizable by a few defining traits. Other than her size, she is almost always black. She typically f...
articles.abstract: At 200 pounds plus -- most of that pure attitude -- she is hard to miss.      Her onscreen presence takes on many variations, but she is easily recognizable by a few defining traits. Other than her size, she is almost always black. She typically finds herself in an exchange that is either confrontational or embarrassing. And her best line is often little more than a sassy ''Mmmm hmmm.''
articles.lead_paragraph: At 200 pounds plus -- most of that pure attitude -- she is hard to miss.

articles.headline: For Lebanese, Calm Moment to Flee Ruins
articles.snippet: In a bathroom, a basement, and a storage room full of yarn, people in this embattled southern town waited for the bombs to stop. They ate pieces of bread, and the grain that they had in their cupboards. Days passed. Food ran out. They began to los...
articles.abstract: In a bathroom, a basement, and a storage room full of yarn, people in this embattled southern town waited for the bombs to stop. They ate pieces of bread, and the grain that they had in their cupboards. Days passed. Food ran out. They began to lose track of time.     On Monday, the first day of a sharp curtailment of Israeli airstrikes, dozens of people emerged, squinting in the searing sun at a scene of destruction so complete that they barely understood what they were looking at. Their town had been crushed, its very heart torn out and pulverized into a chalky dust.
articles.lead_paragraph: BINT JBAIL, Lebanon, July 31 - In a bathroom, a basement, and a storage room full of yarn, people in this embattled southern town waited for the bombs to stop. They ate pieces of bread, and the grain that they had in their cupboards. Days passed. Food ran out. They began to lose track of time.

articles.headline: Tax Cheats Called Out of Control
articles.snippet: So many superrich Americans evade taxes using offshore accounts that law enforcement cannot control the growing misconduct, according to a Senate report that provides the most detailed look ever at high-level tax schemes.     Among the billionaire...
articles.abstract: So many superrich Americans evade taxes using offshore accounts that law enforcement cannot control the growing misconduct, according to a Senate report that provides the most detailed look ever at high-level tax schemes.     Among the billionaires cited in the report are the owner of the New York Jets football team, Robert Wood Johnson IV; the producer of the ''Mighty Morphin Power Rangers'' children's show, Haim Saban; and two Texas businessmen, Charles and Sam Wyly, who the Center for Public Integrity found in 2000 were the ninth-largest contributors to President Bush.

articles.headline: Growing Debate as Doctors Train on New Devices
articles.snippet: Last summer, rival cardiologists in Rock Hill, S.C., decided to learn how to perform a lucrative new procedure, implanting a defibrillator, a device that protects against fatal heart rhythms.      One doctor attended weekend classroom sessions spo...
articles.abstract: Last summer, rival cardiologists in Rock Hill, S.C., decided to learn how to perform a lucrative new procedure, implanting a defibrillator, a device that protects against fatal heart rhythms.      One doctor attended weekend classroom sessions sponsored by a professional medical organization, passed a daylong written test given by that group and implanted defibrillators in 10 patients while an expert observed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, rival cardiologists in Rock Hill, S.C., decided to learn how to perform a lucrative new procedure, implanting a defibrillator, a device that protects against fatal heart rhythms.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Shifts View on Next-Day Pill
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it was moving toward endorsing sale of the morning-after pill without a prescription for women 18 and older, signaling what may be the end of one of the most stubborn health policy debates of th...
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it was moving toward endorsing sale of the morning-after pill without a prescription for women 18 and older, signaling what may be the end of one of the most stubborn health policy debates of the Bush administration.     The agency's acting commissioner, Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach, asked the drug's manufacturer, Barr Pharmaceuticals, for a meeting to complete plans that would allow the over-the-counter sale of the emergency contraceptive, called Plan B. In a statement, the F.D.A. said it hoped ''the process can be wrapped up in a matter of weeks.''
